title: Chamisso Wilderness
text:
Chamisso Wilderness is a <a href="National%20Wilderness%20Preservation%20System">wilderness area</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>. It was designated by the <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a> in 1975.
A small subunit of the Chukchi Sea Unit of the <a href="Alaska%20Maritime%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge</a>, <a href="Chamisso%20Island">Chamisso Island</a> and nearby <a href="Puffin%20Island%2C%20Alaska">Puffin Island</a> were combined as a wildlife refuge in 1912, designated Wilderness in 1975, and added to the AMNWR in 1980.
Chamisso Island, named after the naturalist <a href="Adelbert%20von%20Chamisso">Adelbert von Chamisso</a>, comprises one large <a href="sand%20spit">sand spit</a> and a low beach zone surrounding a covering of <a href="tundra">tundra</a> with a few marshy <a href="bogs">bogs</a>. Although Chamisso Island is much larger, Puffin Island houses many more nesting birds, especially <a href="horned%20puffin">horned puffin</a>s, <a href="black-legged%20kittiwake">black-legged kittiwake</a>s, and <a href="thick-billed%20murre">thick-billed murre</a>s which build their nests on the steep-walled cliffs that fall into <a href="Spafarief%20Bay">Spafarief Bay</a>. <a href="I%C3%B1upiat">Iñupiat</a> cross from the mainland to gather eggs, primarily from <a href="kittiwake">kittiwake</a>s and <a href="murre">murre</a>s. With the exception of birds and the occasional <a href="fox">fox</a> that crosses frozen sea in winter, nothing lives on the islands that make up Chamisso Wilderness. <a href="Walruses">Walruses</a>, <a href="Pinniped">seals</a>, and <a href="whales">whales</a> can often be seen in Spafarief Bay.
